name: Swamp Creek
description:
Don’t judge a canyon by its name! Swamp Creek canyon is a far cry from the image its official designation might suggest. Starting off in a scenic narrows, the canyon soon opens up to reveal many deep pools, unique geology, and some stretches of creekwalking and down climbing between rappels. The approach and exits are very short and easy using the 3 mile shuttle, making this beautiful canyon great bang for your buck.

Canyoneers descending Swamp Creek should have experience rappelling directly in flow, be strong swimmers, and be able to assess/replace V-thread anchors.

Approach

Getting There

From Glacier, WA, head 13 miles east on the Mt. Baker Highway (SR-542). Take a left at NF-32 road (48.90654, -121.69362). Continue for about 0.4 miles and take a left onto one of several side roads. These roads lead back to primitive campsites near Swamp Creek. If these campsites are occupied, it is possible to park along the main road.

Shuttle

Head back out to the Mt. Baker Highway and turn right. After several hundred feet, take another right onto FR-3065 (towards Twin Lakes trailhead). Drive about two miles up the gravel road and turn right onto a side road (48.91706, -121.68105). This road dead ends after a few hundred feet and can fit 2-3 vehicles. Park and suit up here.

Descent

DCR = Down Canyon Right

DCL = Down Canyon Left

Always check for hazards before jumping or sliding! This canyon often has cloudy water from the snowfields in its upper catchment, making visible depth checks difficult. Take extra caution when jumping in this canyon.

From the parking area, there is a use trail down to the creek that only takes a few minutes and begin scrambling down the creek. Within a few minutes you’ll reach the first obstacle as the creek starts to become more narrow.

J1: 5’ jump into shallow pool. This drop can be down climbed or bypassed DCR.

R1: 15’ from a log.

R2/J2: DCR - Traverse 15’ to 25’ rappel, both from unlinked bolt anchors. This rappel puts you directly in the flow, and has also been jumped.

R3: DCR - 18” from a single bolt

After a few hundred feet of downclimbing, you will reach R4.

R4: DCR - 25’ dry rappel from a single bolt.

After R4 there is about a 1/4 mile of scrambling and downclimbing in the creek. Keep an eye out for a pothole where the water seems to disappear!

R5: DCR - 20' from a single bolt

R6: DCR - 20' from a single bolt

R7: DCL - 50’ from unlinked bolts. This rappel takes you down a giant log wedged in the creek. There is a large pothole hidden beneath the log. Take special care not to swing into this pothole while on rope.

R8/S1: DCR - 60’ from unlinked bolts. This drop also goes as a slide from about 1/3 of the way down. It is possible to scramble back up from the bottom to lap this slide.

R9/J2: DCR - 25’ from unlinked bolts. This drop has also been jumped into the narrow pool below.

Directly after R8, down climb a tricky slab DCR. For a less exposed route down, it is possible to scramble across the creek and rappel off a logjam DCL.

R10: 15’ from a logjam or downclimb through the logs.

R11: DCR - 40’ from a single bolt on a boulder. This rappel has an awkward start.

R12: DCL - 35’ from a V-thread into a pool. It is important to set rope length here to avoid entanglement. There is an alcove on canyon left that less confident swimmers can be pushed into. Sending a strong swimmer first to assist others out of the pool is recommended. R10 and R11 are in the same sequence.

R13: DCL - 15’ from a single bolt.

Exit

After R11, continue down the creek for another 5-10 minutes until the creekbed opens up. Find a spot to cut up into the woods DCL and find the use trail that will take you to the campsites/parking area next to the creek.

Red tape

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Background

This canyon was first descended on 9/3/22 by Jake Huddleston, Tiffanie Lin, Andrew Humphreys, Kevin Steffa, Erik Bernhoft, Tre C Kwan, and Michael Henson.
